Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Paleodemographic Analysis of Urbanization, Famine and Mortality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Rapid increases in population density resulting from urban expansion facilitate the transmission of infectious diseases, unsanitary living conditions, and precarious food supplies. The potential negative effects of urbanism in living populations are of considerable interest to public health experts, particularly the ways in which urban factors play a role in the development and severity of disease. Research on urbanization in the past provides temporal depth to our understanding of the consequences of urbanism. This project will examine patterns of health and diet in medieval London (c. 1120-1539) to investigate the relationship between pathology and nutrition in the context of urbanization. Paleodemographic and biochemical analyses of skeletal samples from medieval England will be used to investigate urbanization and famine, combining approaches in a unique way that will advance research in biological anthropology. The project will be generally informative about environmental pressures that affect human health and adaptability to changing environments. Broader impacts include training of a female graduate student, public science outreach efforts, and development of international collaborations.

This 12-month dissertation project integrates paleodemographic (hazard analysis) and biochemical (stable isotope analysis) approaches to examine the health and diet of inhabitants in medieval London and to investigate the interaction of pathology and nutrition on mortality during urbanization and incidences of famine. Skeletal data from the urban St. Mary Spital cemetery and rural Barton-upon-Humber cemetery will be analyzed to determine how morbidity and mortality patterns in medieval London changed over time as a result of increased urbanization; evaluate how temporal changes in morbidity and mortality of medieval London compare to a contemporaneous rural population; investigate the relationship between diet and health during the transition to a more urban environment by integrating paleodemographic approaches with stable isotope analysis; and examine how potential biochemical markers of famine are manifested in medieval London using stable isotope analysis, including an innovative incremental dentine analysis method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transitional periods, such as urbanization, are of particular interest to bioarchaeologists, as several have concluded that increasing social and economic complexity is associated with dramatic declines in health. During the Late Medieval period, London underwent intensive urbanization, resulting in detrimental living conditions (e.g. increased levels of infection from overcrowding, inadequate sanitation services, and precarious food supplies) that may have affected the health of the population. To evaluate patterns of mortality, as a proxy for health, in an urbanizing environment, this project assessed over 800 Late Medieval English human skeletons (c. 1120-1539) from a medieval urban cemetery in London (St Mary Spital) and a contemporaneous non-urban cemetery in Lincolnshire (St Peter’s). Rib and tooth samples were collected from St Mary Spital cemetery and are currently being analyzed to evaluate dietary patterns within the urban population and across time periods, and to examine potential biochemical markers of famine.

 

The results of this project are informative about how, historically, urbanization affected health in human populations and which subpopulations are most at risk during urban expansion. Comparison of the cemeteries via hazards and survival analysis indicate that urban adults, in general, experienced elevated mortality and reduced survivorship. Environmental factors that are characteristic of urban centers such as high population density, elevated risk of disease, poor sanitary conditions, and famine may have contributed to the detrimental effect of the urban environment on adult health, and thus mortality and survival. Analysis by sex, suggests that females in the urban sample experienced elevated risks of mortality and reduced survival compared to non-urban females, whereas males faced equal risks in both environments. These sex differences in mortality may be a consequence of a higher proportion of females migrating from non-urban to urban centers in search of work opportunities, who may also have suffered from poverty, famine, and exposure to pathogens during immigration or upon their arrival in the city. Further, comparison of early and late time periods within the cemeteries using survival analysis indicate that for adults in the urban environment, survivorship increased with the intensification of urbanization, but did not change for non-urban adults. Separate analyses of the sexes reveal that female survivability did not change as urbanization progressed, while males experienced increased survivorship through time. For urban subadults, survivability did not change with increased urbanization. These results may reflect changes in strategies and policies to accommodate sanitation and pollution issues necessitated by increased population density in London. Changes in living conditions may have benefitted adults as urbanization progressed, but may not have been as effective for females and subadults.

 

The results of this project reveal that subpopulations did not experience the hazards of urbanization equally. For example, the elevated mortality and reduced survival for urban females compared to rural females was apparent once the sexes were analyzed separately, and may have contributed to the overall mortality differences of adults between the urban and rural cemeteries. This demonstrates that though general comparisons of cemeteries are informative about broad demographic differences or similarities, it is important to use approaches that allow for the examination of heterogeneity in past populations so that intra-population variation in mortality patterns can be identified and potential disproportionate affects of urbanization on subpopulations may be revealed. The results for carbon and nitrogen stable isotopic analysis of bone and tooth samples from the urban cemetery were delayed and analyses are currently being conducted. Preliminary analyses of rib bone samples reveal significant differences in diet between different time periods within and between different age groups.

 

The results of this project have been and will continue to be presented at professional conferences, and will also be presented in talks that are open to the general public. Results from this project have been published in academic journals and deposited in the University of South Carolina’s Institutional Repository, which is accessible to the general public. Additionally, this project contributed to diversity in STEM research by supporting the training of a first-generation female graduate student in hazard analysis techniques and interpretation, provided continued experience with estimating adult age using transition analysis, and instruction in the interpretation of stable isotope data. Finally, results from this project can potentially benefit modern populations by informing public health strategies for areas experiencing urbanization, specifically by identifying groups that may be disproportionally affected (e.g. females).
